title: Ability To Delete User(s) Account Without User Interaction
content:
Summary:
Gitlab allows its user to exercise their GDPR rights (Right to Access/Delete) user data by sending an email to gdpr-request@gitlab.com however gitlab team doesn't ask for security question(i.e Date Of Birth) before deleting the user account moreover doesn't authenticate the incoming emails from their instance which allows an attacker to delete user accounts without user interaction :
██████
Steps to reproduce
Send an spoofed email from victim's email address to gdpr-request@gitlab.com from a reputable SMTP (e.g: Sendgrid): ███████
Victim will receive the following confirmation email:
<image_0>
██████
Fix :
Add second verification i.e ask for DOB,Government ID.
Impact
Since Gitlab doesn't verify the request with an Valid ID before triggering Right to Access/Deletion this breaches the GDPR Law(Article 15) & moreover allows an attacker to delete User Accounts without user interaction.
steps: Send a spoofed email from the victim's email address to gdpr-request@gitlab.com using a reputable SMTP service (e.g., Sendgrid).
Victim receives a confirmation email, and the account deletion is processed without further verification.
vuln_description: GitLab allows users to request account deletion via email (gdpr-request@gitlab.com) without verifying the sender's identity or requiring additional authentication (e.g., date of birth or government ID). This flaw enables an attacker to spoof the victim's email and request account deletion without user interaction, violating GDPR Article 15.
reason: The vulnerability involves a straightforward attack vector (email spoofing) and lacks any complex interactions or novel logic. The absence of multi-factor verification makes it easy to exploit.
